When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults wai

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's sill

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me,"

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into yo

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. W

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we?" Tears well in

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we?" Tears well in his own eye

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People li

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping insid

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store's automatic doo

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"

You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

"Due to the violent development of suicidal-homocidal tendencies in adults who have received anti-ageing treat

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.


"Due to the violent development of suicidal-homocidal tendencies in adults who have received anti-ageing treatment, we ask that all members of

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.


"Due to the violent development of suicidal-homocidal tendencies in adults who have received anti-ageing treatment, we ask that all members of the affected population (ages 2

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.


"Due to the violent development of suicidal-homocidal tendencies in adults who have received anti-ageing treatment, we ask that all members of the affected population (ages 26-83) turn themselves in for cont

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.


"Due to the violent development of suicidal-homocidal tendencies in adults who have received anti-ageing treatment, we ask that all members of the affected population (ages 26-83) turn themselves in for containment. This fa

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.


"Due to the violent development of suicidal-homocidal tendencies in adults who have received anti-ageing treatment, we ask that all members of the affected population (ages 26-83) turn themselves in for containment. This facility has beeen

When you're 28, science discovers a drug that stops all effects of aging, creating immortality. Your government decides to give the drug to all citizens under 26, but you and the rest of the “Lost Generations" are deemed too high-risk. When you're 85, the side effects are finally discovered.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.
“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

Because of that, you don't even hear about the breakthrough discovery until weeks after it's become a global sensation. The first time you hear about it, you're in the middle of a crowd of young adults waiting to get into the grocery store.

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.

By then, the world is almost entirely filled with bright-eyed, attractive, youthful young adults. People like you have to hide on the edges of society, avoiding their judgemental gazes at all costs as you become more and more decrepit and they remain strikingly beautiful.

“Agirl in front of you tin the line spots you and grabs you by the shoulders.

"You're one of the lucky ones," she weeps, nearly knocking you off your feet with her youthful strength. "You're one of the Lost Generations, aren't you?"

It's silly that she needs to ask, because it's obvious. But you nod anyways.

Her tears fall faster. "Please remember me," she sobs, flinging herself into your arms and squeezing your shoulders in a tight embrace. "Remember all of us when we... when we..."

Her words choke to a halt, leaving you baffled and afraid.

A young man approaches you and places his hand on her back. He also looks sad.
"We're sorry," he says. to you. "For all the times people like us... well. We didn't know, of course. And we never got the choice, did we? People like us... this is the end of the line, isn't it?"
You don't know what to say.
 You have no idea what they're talking about. So you nod, hoping it might mean something to them.

Sniffling, the girl detaches from you and takes the young man's hand. "Please remember us," she repeats, giving you one last mournful stare before stepping through the store door.

As the automated door shuts behind her, you realize it's covered in a large poster, marked with the seal of the government. It's a warning about the side effects of the immortality drug.
You read the poster, and the world falls out from under you.
